newsitem.title: UK: Vodafone unveils new corporate identity.
newsitem.headline: Vodafone unveils new corporate identity.

text.p: Vodafone Group Plc, Britain's biggest mobile telephone company, unveiled its new corporate identity on Monday in a move which will see it reorganise its six service provider chains into three new businesses.
It said that the three companies will eventually move to a unified billing system. The reorganisation will see around 300 jobs phased out over the next 18 months.
At present, the service provision companies have five different billing systems, six customer care systems, twelve different brands and 87 different tariffs.
It said the changes would bring greater operational efficiency and overhead cost savings, but expected that current year profits would likely be reduced by 20 million pounds ($33.8 million).

However, the company sees an improvement of 10 million pounds the following year and of 35 million by the third year. It also expects that staff numbers will exceed present levels within 18 months as a result of customer growth.
Vodafone also said that "better co-ordinated advertising and more effective distribution" would produce a 20 percent rise in net customer growth over the next two to three years.

"We believe that these changes are a fundamental pre-requisite to achieving higher growth in the years to come and to sustaining Vodafone's position as the UK market leader," said chief executive Chris Gent.

The reorganisation will see the three new businesses, the company's shops and all the group's UK companies trade under the same identity - Vodafone. The total cost of changing premises, literature and vehicles to the new identity will be 15 million pounds.
The company's outlets that sell its telephones, include Vodac, Vodacall, Vodacom Talkland, Peoplesphone and Astec.
These will now create the three new business units - Vodafone Retail, Vodafone Connect and Vodafone Corporate. The mergers will take place over 18 months.
